SEM image (a) and the distribution of nickel (b), carbon (c), iron (d), platinum (e), nitrogen (f), oxygen (g), and sulfur (h); elemental composition of the Ni foam functionalized by hemoglobin molecules (i) Figure 3 Typical cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of (a) Ni foam and Ni foam functionalized with 0.68 mg of hemeproteins (b) CytC, (c) Mb, and (d) Hb immobilized onto NF electrode in 6 mol/L NaOH at different scan rates. Insert is the correlation between peak currents and square root of the scan rate; total mass of the electrode is 100.68 mg Figure 4 Galvanostatic discharge curves at different discharge currents (0.4 mA to 10 mA) in 6 mol/L NaOH for protein films (a) Hb, (b) Mb, and (c) CytC. (d) Calculated capacitance as a function of discharging current for different electrodes. Capacitance was calculated based on the total mass of the electrode (100.68 mg) Figure 5 (a) Galvanostatic discharge curves of different masses of Hb immobilized on the Ni-foam electrode in 6 mol/L NaOH at a discharge current of 1.0 mA, (b) Nyquist of porous Ni foam and Hb film at 0.55 V vs. Ag/AgCl in the frequency range between 100 kHz and 10 mHz. The excitation voltage was 5 mV Figure 6 Durability and cycling performance of 3D porous Ni foam/protein electrodes (a) Hb and (b) Mb in 6 mol/L NaOH at 0.4 mA Scheme 1 Schematic representation of the charge/discharge redox mechanism of the NF protein film. x: the thickness of the Ni(II) layer; y: the thickness of the protein film Promising supercapacitor electrodes based immobilization of proteins onto macroporous Ni foam materials Mohamed Khairy a # Sherif A. El-Safty a b * a National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), 1-2-1 Sengen, Tsukubałshi, Ibaraki-ken 305-0047, Japan National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) 1-2-1 Sengen Tsukubałshi Ibaraki-ken 305-0047 Japan b Graduate School for Advanced Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169-8555, Japan Graduate School for Advanced Science and Engineering Waseda University 3-4-1 Okubo Shinjuku-ku Tokyo 169-8555 Japan * Corresponding author. Tel: +81-298592135; Fax: +81-298592025 # Current address: Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Sohag University, Egypt Immobilizing biocomponents on solid surfaces is a critical step in the development of new devices for future biological, medical, and electronic applications. Therefore, numerous integrated films were recently developed by immobilizing different proteins or enzymes on electrode surfaces. In this work, hemeproteins were safely immobilized onto macroporous nickel-based electrodes while maintaining their functionality. Such modified electrodes showed interesting pseudo-capacitive behavior. Among hemeproteins, hemoglobin (Hb) film has a higher electrochemical performance and greater charge/discharge cycling stability than myoglobin (Mb) and cytochrome C (CytC). The heme group in an alkaline medium could induce the formation of superoxides on the electrode surface. These capacitive features of hemeprotein-Ni electrode were related to strong binding sites between hemeproteins and porous Ni electrode, the accumulation of superoxide or radicals on the Ni surface, and facile electron transfer and electrolyte diffusion through the three-dimensional macroporous network. Thus, these new protein-based supercapacitors have potential use in free-standing platform technology for the development of implantable energy-storage devices. A supercapacitor electrode based on immobilization of hemeproteins into macroporous nickel foam was developed. The hemeprotein increases the active material usage due to rapid electron transfer in addition to storage reservoir for ions and radicals. Key words hemeprotein nickel foam pseudocapacitor macroporous peroxide alkaline medium 1 Introduction In response to the increasing energy needs of modern society, electrochemical energy-storage systems have become more important because of the limitations in renewable energy production by the sun and wind as well as in the development of electric or hybrid electric vehicles with low CO2 emission [1]. At the forefront of these energy-storage devices are rechargeable batteries and electrochemical supercapacitors (ECs). ECs have received greater interest than batteries because the latter suffer from relatively slow power delivery or uptake; thus, faster and higher-power energy-storage systems are needed [2,3]. ECs are the best candidates for energy storage because of their unique energy buffers, reliable life cycle (10000 cycles), low internal resistance, fast charge and discharge rates, high power densities, and their applicability in biological environments [4]. However, numerous problems prevent supercapacitors from becoming commercially viable primary power supplies. In particular, their energy density is low, and most fabrication processes are costly and inappropriate for large-scale manufacturing [2,5]. Thus, constructing an inexpensive, recyclable, and biocompatible supercapacitor with high power and high energy densities has become a challenge for the future of energy-storage devices. Supercapacitor electrodes are prepared by mixing electro-active materials with conductive carbon additives and a polymeric binder dissolved in a solvent. The produced slurry is then cast onto nickel foam current collectors and dried. Previous studies have focused on the synthesis of active porous nanomaterials with improved properties. Electro-active materials include metal oxides/hydroxides [6–10] or sulfides [11], and carbon-based materials [12,13]. In addition to being conductive, polymers are also capable of storing charge pseudo-capacitively (200 F/g to 3000 F/g) [13]. These nanomaterials provide high capacitance but are costly, tedious to fabricate, and difficult to scale up. To overcome this drawback, Malvankar et al. [14] suggested the use of a conductive microbial biofilm on a gold electrode to enhance the capacitance of the device. The electrochemical performance of a Geobacter sulfurreducens biofilm is related to the heme groups of c-type cytochromes (CytCs), which readily provide a large electron-storage capacity. Thus, CytC functions as an electron sink as well as a capacitor. Our group has recently presented nanomagnet-selective hemeproteins CytC, myoglobin (Mb), and hemoglobin (Hb) based on NiO nanoparticles (NPs). In addition to heme group distributions and protein-carrier binding energy, the morphology and magnetic properties of NiO NPs are found to have vital functions in improving the controlled immobilization affinity and selectivity of hemeproteins [15]. Metalloproteins containing heme binding sites within various protein scaffolds have crucial functions in electron transfer, substrate oxidation, metal ion storage, ligand sensing, and transport [16]. Thus, the breadth of electrochemical function in proteins of a known structure has provided a wealth of information on various factors that set and modulate heme redox activity. Moreover, the demand for more sustainable and efficient energy-storage devices has led to a renewed scientific and commercial interest in advanced supercapacitor designs. This study proposes a simple design of low-cost and ecofriendly supercapacitor based on the functionality of hemeproteins. Novel supercapacitor electrodes were developed using commercially available three-dimensional (3D) macroporous Ni-foam immobilized with hemeproteins (Scheme 1 ). The specific capacitance was enhanced by about five times compared with that of the Ni foam. The proof of the concept is provided by determining the unusual binding efficiency of the porous magnetic nickel-based material and the hemeproteins (∼E ads = −211.45 kcal/mol) as well as that of the binding affinity of the latter with oxygen molecules that enhance the redox process through the heme group [15]. Moreover, the 3D nanostructure protein network, magnetic character, and porous architecture of the Ni electrode are key factors that affect the application of our supercapacitor in energy-storage devices. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents All materials were used without further purification. Cytochrome C (CytC, 12.384 kDa, 3.0 nm), myoglobin (Mb, 16.950 kDa, 4.0 nm), and hemoglobin (Hb, 68.000 kDa, 7.0 nm) were obtained from Sigma-Adrich Company Ltd., USA. The sodium hydroxide is obtained from Wako Company Ltd. Osaka, Japan. 2.2 Supercapacitor electrodes: characterization and preparation FESEM images were measured by a field-emission scanning electron microscopy (JEOL model 6500). The SEM micrographs were operated at 15 keV to better record the SEM images of Ni foam samples. Before insertion into the chamber the Ni foam was fixed on a SEM stage using carbon double side tapes. The Pt films were deposited on adsorbent substrates at room temperature using a fine coat ion-sputter (JEOL model JFC-11000). The distance between the target and the adsorbent substrate was 5.0 cm. The sputtering deposition system used for the experiments consists of a stainless steel chamber, which was evacuated down to 8×10−5 Pa with a turbomolecular pump backed up by a rotary pump. Before sputtering deposition, the Pt target (10 nm diameter, purity 99.95%) was sputter cleaned in pure Ar. The Ar working pressure (2.8×10−1 Pa), the power supply (100 W) and the deposition rate were kept constant throughout these investigations. Moreover, the elemental analyses were done by energy-dispersive X-ray micro-analyzers (EDX) using an X-ray micro-analyzer integrated in the FESEM instrument. A three-electrode system was used to measure the electrochemical properties. Cyclic voltammetry, galvanostatic charge-discharge and electrochemical impedance spectroscopic measurements techniques were carried out using an electrochemical workstations provided by Zennium/ZAHNER-Elektrik GmbH & CoKG, which was controlled by the Thales Z 2.0 software. Ni foam (1 mm×1 cm×2 cm, Nilaco Co.) used as the working electrode and substrate for hemeprotein immobilization. Ni foam with a pore size ranging from 450 μm to 3.2 mm was prepared using chemical vapor deposition or electrodeposition and subsequently sintered at an elevated temperature. A platinum mesh and an Ag/AgCl/3 mol/L NaCl electrode were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. Ni foam was carefully cleaned with a solution of (1 mol/L) HCl in an ultrasound bath for 5 min to remove the surface NiO layer. Then, deionized water and absolute ethanol were used several times for completely clean. A specific amount of hemeprotein was dropped onto the Ni foam electrode and dried at 60 °C prior to the electrochemical analysis. A freshly prepared 6 mol/L NaOH solution was used as the supporting electrolyte. The specific capacitance (C s) was derived from the CV measurements using the following equation [6]: (1) C s = 1 v m ( Δ V ) ∫ V a V c i V d V where C s is the specific capacitance in F/g, ν is the voltammetric sweep rate in V/s, ΔV is the potential window (V a to V c) in V, and m is the total mass of the electrode (Ni foam and protein) in g. The specific capacitance was also calculated from the charge/discharge curves using the following equation: (2) C s = I × Δ t m × ( Δ V ) The energy density (E) and power density (P) of the supercapacitor were derived from the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves at different current densities. The energy density was calculated using the following equation: (3) E = 1 2 C s ( Δ V ) 2 The specific power density was calculated using the following equation: (4) P = E Δ t Where, ΔV is the potential drop during the discharge in V, I is the applied discharge current in A, and Δt is the discharge time in s. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural features of Ni-protein electrode The 3D open-macropore architecture has gained increased research interest because of its unique physical feature of high surface-to-volume ratio [17]. This material is widely applied in catalysis, separation systems, and chemical sensors [18–20]. Ni foam is commercially available and possesses distinct features of exceptional uniformity, light weight, inertness, high porosity, mechanical strength, corrosion resistance, as well as high magnetic, electrical, and thermal conductivities. Figure 1 shows a typical SEM image of Ni foam (Figure 1a and 1b) and Ni foam functionalized with Hb electrodes (Figure 1c and 1d). A 3D-crosslinked grid structure containing small and large open pores ranging from 50 μm to 500 μm is observed. Large pores dominate the 3D structure, whereas small pores are mostly observed in the regions where grains interconnect. Higher-magnification SEM images (Figure 1b and 1d) show a compact macroporous structure of interconnected grain-like vertebrae with narrow grain boundaries. The vertebrae exhibit spherical shapes with diameters of 10 μm. When Hb is dropped onto the Ni foam surface, a fairly uniform film is formed over the external surface of the macroporous network backbone with a thickness of ∼80 nm. The uniform distribution of Hb is due to its high binding affinity with a Ni-based material [15]. Such 3D networks of NF provide an interconnected, electrolyte-filled macroporous network that guarantees high accessibility and enables rapid ion transport. The chemical composition and distribution mapping of the Ni-protein film is shown in Figure 2 . The EDX map shows a 3D macroporous network consisting of Ni, C, Pt, O, N, S, and Fe images. Ni atoms are uniformly distributed over the entire NF surface area. Hb comprised C, O, N, S, and Fe atoms, and the elemental ratio of the NF hybrid indicates that the Ni foam is in pure form (Figure 1). The extended surface area and fine-tuned 3D structure of the Ni foam make it a suitable electrode for various electrochemical applications (Equations 5–7) [21]. 3.2 Electrochemical behavior of Ni-protein electrode The hemeprotein modified Ni foam electrodes were investigated using cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge/discharge, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopic measurements. Figure 3 shows the typical CV curves of the Ni foam and the Ni foam modified with protein films in 6 mol/L NaOH as recorded at different voltage scan rates. CV curves are mainly characteristic of Faradic pseudocapacitance materials. Initially, the electrodes were stabilized for 20 cycles in strong alkaline media prior to the final measurements. These CV cycles indicate the formation of active sublayers from Ni(OH)2 and Ni(OH)− 3 according to the Pourbaix diagram, as presented in Equations (5–7) [21]. The CV curves show a pair of redox current peaks related to the oxidation of the Ni(II) /Ni(III) species as presented in Equations (5–7) [21,22]. The anodic peak potential of the Ni foam-protein film shifts toward a more positive potential with increasing scan rate. The peak-to-peak separation ΔE p (E pa–E pc) increases, and the ratios of the current peaks (I pa/I pc) approach unity. The asymmetrical nature of the redox peaks indicates the quasi-reversible redox process of the Ni foam-protein film. The peak current is linearly correlated with υ 1/2, which indicates that the electrochemical process is controlled by the diffusion of [OH−] into the macroporous network (inset of Figure 3(a–d)). The peak current of Hb film is enhanced by approximately three times more than that of the Ni-foam electrode. These findings indicate that the Hb film enhances electron transfer rate of the Ni-foam electrode. Moreover, the slight shift in the peak potentials of the Ni foam-protein film may be due to the dehydration of Ni(OH)2 and Ni(OH)− 3 or to the formation of a NiO sublayer, depending on the protein type (Scheme 1) [22]. (5) Ni + OH - → NiOH ads + e - (6) NiOH ads + OH - → Ni ( OH ) 2 + e - (7) Ni ( OH ) 2 + OH - → NiOOH + H 2 O + e - Hemeproteins exhibit a nanostructured network with a porous architecture [14]. Specifically, Hb is an intelligent molecule because it varies its activity in response to environmental stimuli [23]. In alkaline media, the immobilized Hb shows a higher surface activation for the 3D macroporous network of Ni foam than those of Mb and CytC (Figure 3d). Therefore, the nanostructured metalloproteins on the 3D macroporous network with the active film are the major factors that affect the performance of supercapacitors. Specific capacitance values are calculated from CV measurements according to Equation (1). The specific capacitance of the Hb film is 12.18 F/g compared with 10.2, 9.8, and 3.5 F/g for the Mb, CytC, and Ni foams alone, respectively, at 5 mV/s. The specific capacitance is calculated based on the total weight of electrode (weight of Ni foam + weight of protein). The high specific capacitance of the Hb film is due to the rapid electron transfer caused by the strong binding affinity between the heme group and the Ni surface [15,21]. This binding affinity may increase the active usage of surface materials and enhance the electron transfer and diffusion of ions through the 3D macroporous network. This outstanding electrochemical performance of the Hb film supercapacitor is expected to provide high specific energy or high specific capacitance in rapid charge/discharge processes. This integrated phenomenon of specific capacitance caused by the increase in the active sites of the electrode material via direct immobilization of commercially available biomolecules may open a new avenue for the fabrication of electric energy-storage devices. Rate capability is one of the relevant parameters used to evaluate the supercapacitors performance. The constantcurrent galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of the Ni-protein film electrode at different discharge currents were measured (Figure 4 ). Regardless of the applied discharge current value, nonlinear curves are observed for all protein films. The Hb film exhibited a longer discharge time than Mb and CytC, which indicates that Hb film enhances electrochemical reactivity with lower polarization. This finding has been previously confirmed via CV measurements (Figure 3). The supercapacitor specific capacitance can be determined by performing a charge/discharge experiment according to Equation (2), and the results are presented in Figure 4(d). At 0.4 mA, Hb film has a specific capacitance of 13.8 F/g, whereas those of Mb and CytC are 8.9 and 8.2 F/g, respectively. The specific capacitance is calculated based on the total weight of the Ni foam electrode (100 mg) and the protein film. However, the specific capacitance values related only to the weight of the protein film are calculated as 2052, 1460, and 1213 F/g for Hb, Mb, and CytC, respectively. Noticeably, the specific capacitance of the Hb, Mb, and CytC films remain as high as 11.9, 8.2, and 6.9 F/g, respectively, even when the discharge current was increased to 10 mA. These findings reveal that the capacitance is enhanced by about five times more than that from the Ni foam electrode when protein films are used. These results indicate the capability of Ni-foam protein film electrodes in developing supercapacitors technology. Figure 5(a) shows the reliability of Ni foam Hb film electrodes due to the immobilization of various Hb quantities on the Ni-foam electrode surface. A direct correlation between the immobilized Hb mass and specific capacitance is observed, which indicates the high stability, high capability rate, and applicability of Hb film for high-performance supercapacitor applications. The capacitive behavior of Ni foam and Ni foam-Hb film electrode was investigated using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements. In the high-frequency region, the Ni foam and the Hb film display a very small semicircle followed by an inclined straight line in the low-frequency region, which is characteristic of Warburg behavior as shown in Figure 5(b). For the Hb film, the straight line is close to the vertical line along the imaginary axis because of the accumulation of electrolyte ions on the electrode surface, which reveals the ideal capacitive behavior of the electrode. These results support CV and galvanostatic discharge measurements and reflect the diffusion process. Galvanostatic tests were also performed to demonstrate the advantages of the Ni foam protein film as a supercapacitor electrode. Figure 5 illustrates a continuous galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling at a constant current of 0.4 mA over 1000 cycles in the representative voltage profile from 0.65 V to 0.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) in 6 mol/L NaOH. The porous Hb film shows a markedly superior cycling behavior (Figure 6 ). At 1000 cycles, the capacitance retention drops by only 2.5% of its initial value, but the specific capacitance of Mb decreases by 28.4%. In this system, hemeproteins are directly used without conductive carbon additives or even a polymeric binder. These results suggest that the Hb film-based supercapacitor maintains high electrochemical performance and high stability without sacrificing much of its specific capacitance. This superior pseudocapacitive behavior is of great interest and can be attributed to the rapid electron transfer, impressive binding between Hb and Ni electrode, and formation of superoxide and/or peroxide that enhance the surface active sites of the Ni-foam electrode. These phenomena are shown in CV and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements. To understand the capacitive behavior behind the Ni-Hb platform, Banks et al. [21] suggested the evaluation of oxygen molecules in strong alkaline media at a relatively high voltage (+0.65 V vs. SCE) of a nickel oxide screen-printed electrode as follows: (8) 4OH - ⇌ O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - This electrochemical reaction is also catalyzed by the redox coupling of nickel species (Ni2+/Ni3+) [6,22]. Regarding the biological functionality of hemeprotein, the heme group has crucial physiological functions referred to as gasotransmitters in biological systems. Hb consists of four polypeptides and four heme groups, whereas Mb consists of a single polypeptide chain and two heme groups that can bind to oxygen molecules. Hb can bind four O2 molecules (vs. one for Mb) and exhibits a sigmoid shape that closely resembles allosteric enzymes. CytC is an essential component of the electron-transfer chain but does not bind oxygen molecules [23,24]. Theoretically, the immobilization of 0.136 g Hb on the Ni foam electrode surface can accumulate and store approximately 4.82×1015 molecules of oxygen. Moreover, these oxygenated heme groups of proteins (Hb and Mb) lead to the formation of superoxides in the active heme pockets [25]. These superoxide radicals can accumulate on electrode surfaces where metal atoms are under-coordinated and can react further to form surface-adsorbed HO· or O− 2. In terms of its bonding with surface metal atoms, adsorbed HO· forms an open-shell structure. Mb functions as an oxygen-storage protein rather than an oxygen-transport protein (Hb) because it has a very strong binding affinity to oxygen molecules. Moreover, its structure helps prevent superoxides (O− 2) from leaving the heme group [24]. These findings indicate that Hb, instead of Mb and CytC, causes the high surface activation because of the transport of superoxides into the 3D macroporous network of the Ni foam. In addition, the superoxides may be catalyzed by iron in the heme groups to form peroxide radicals in situ using Fenton's reagent (Scheme 1) [26]. (9) Fe 3 + + H 2 O 2 ⇌ Fe 2 + + OOH · + H + These findings indicate that immobilizing Hb on the surface of the Ni foam as the working electrode in a strong alkaline medium leads to the formation of superoxide and/or peroxide radicals, which enhance the surface active sites of Ni foam. This protein film subsequently increases the active material usage because of rapid electron transfer, in addition to the storage reservoir for ions and radicals. These interesting phenomena caused by the merging of hemeproteins and the macroporous Ni foam indicate the occurrence of powerful, highly stable Faradic reactions even at high current densities (Figure 4). 4 Conclusions A simple and low-cost supercapacitor design based on commercial 3D open-pore Ni foam and hemeproteins (Hb, Mb, and CytC) was developed. Proteins were immobilized on the Ni surface without the use of conducting carbon or polymeric binder. Among the hemeproteins used in this study, the Hb film showed higher specific capacitance, excellent cyclic stability, good reliability, and very good retention at high current densities. Such features make the Ni foam-Hb film one of the promising electrode design for supercapacitor applications. This safe immobilization of biological components on porous electrodes may open avenues for designing advanced electrode materials. coredata.dc:description: Immobilizing biocomponents on solid surfaces is a critical step in the development of new devices for future biological, medical, and electronic applications. Therefore, numerous integrated films were recently developed by immobilizing different proteins or enzymes on electrode surfaces. In this work, hemeproteins were safely immobilized onto macroporous nickel-based electrodes while maintaining their functionality. Such modified electrodes showed interesting pseudo-capacitive behavior. Among hemeproteins, hemoglobin (Hb) film has a higher electrochemical performance and greater charge/discharge cycling stability than myoglobin (Mb) and cytochrome C (CytC). The heme group in an alkaline medium could induce the formation of superoxides on the electrode surface. These capacitive features of hemeprotein-Ni electrode were related to strong binding sites between hemeproteins and porous Ni electrode, the accumulation of superoxide or radicals on the Ni surface, and facile electron transfer and electrolyte diffusion through the three-dimensional macroporous network. Thus, these new protein-based supercapacitors have potential use in free-standing platform technology for the development of implantable energy-storage devices.

coredata.dc:title: Promising supercapacitor electrodes based immobilization of proteins onto macroporous Ni foam materials
